src.tasks package

Submodules

src.tasks.task module

This module defines the Task class for managing tasks.

class src.tasks.task.Task(name: str, due_date: str, description: str = '', completion: int = 0)[source]

Bases: object

The Task class represents a task.

Example Usage:

# Create a new task
task = Task(
    "My task", datetime.datetime(2022, 1, 1),
    "This is task 1", 50, "Project A"
)

# Set the completion percentage of the task
task1.set_completion(75)

# Get all tasks
all_tasks = Task.get_all_tasks()

Fields:

  • id_task: A counter to generate unique task IDs.

  • instances: A list to store all task instances.

control_completion_validity()[source]

Decorate a function to control the validity of completion percentage.

Parameters:

func (callable) – The function to be decorated.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

callable

Raises:

ValueError – If the completion percentage is not in the range [0, 100].

control_date_validity()[source]

Decorate a function to control the validity of due dates.

This decorator ensures that due dates are in the format

‘DD/MM/YYYY’, and they are set to today or a future date.

Parameters:

func (callable) – The function to be decorated.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

callable

Raises:

ValueError – If the date format is incorrect or if the date is not today or a future date.

func (callable) – The function to be decorated.

Returns:

The decorated function.

Return type:

callable

Raises:

ValueError – If the description length exceeds 100 characters.

create_task(name: str, due_date: str, description: str, completion: int)[source]

Create a task with the specified attributes threw class setters.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the task.

  • due_date (str) – The due date of the task (in the format ‘DD/MM/YYYY’).

  • description (str) – An optional description of the task.

  • completion (int) – An optional completion percentage (0 to 100).

src.tasks.tasklist module

This module provides a TaskList class to manage a list of tasks.

class src.tasks.tasklist.TaskList[source]

Bases: object

The TaskList class manages a list of tasks.

Example Usage:

# Create a new task list
task_list = TaskList()

# Add a new task to the list
task_list.add_task(
    "Task 1", "25/12/2024", "Description for Task 1", completion=0
)

# Display all tasks in the list
task_list.display_tasks()
add_task(name: str, due_date: str, description: str = '', completion: int = 0)[source]

Add a new task to the task list.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the task.

  • due_date (str) – The due date of the task (in string format).

  • description (str) – Additional description of the task (default is an empty string).

  • completion (int) – The completion status of the task (default is 0).

Mark a task as completed by its unique identifier.

Parameters:

id (int) – The unique identifier of the task to mark as completed.

Mark a task as completed by its name.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the task to mark as completed.
